Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs McMurphy: Steve Spurrier changed college football Bobby Lewis, WTSP 11:23 p.m. EDT October 13, 2015 Oct 10, 2015; Baton Rouge, LA, USA; South Carolina Gamecocks head coach Steve Spurrier runs off the field following a loss against the LSU Tigers in a game at Tiger Stadium. LSU defeated South Carolina 45-24. (Photo: Derick E. Hingle, Derick E. Hingle-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
In the first 83 years of Florida football, the Gators won exactly zero conference championships. Steve Spurrier walked in the door in 1990 and the brought six SEC titles to Gainesville in the next 12 seasons. 
"I would argue he had the biggest impact on the SEC than any other coach. Bigger than Bear Bryant. Bigger than Nick Saban, because he changed the culture," ESPN college football insider Brett McMurphy said in an interview at the 10News studio Tuesday afternoon. "He changed the way the game was played and he also elevate the entire conference." 
Spurrier arrived at Florida and saw other SEC teams running the ball all game. He decided to install his own pass-oriented style of play, what media members would affectionately nickname the "Fun-and-gun" offense. Reactions from ESPN staff writer Brett McMurphy about South Carolina Head Coach Steve Spurrier's sudden resignation. 
Overnight, the landscape of college football changed. 
"You had to compete with them and if you didn't, you were going to get beat and you were going to get beat bad," said McMurphy. 
Spurrier went on to win the 1996 national championship over the rival Florida State Seminoles. Read or Share this story: http://on.wtsp.com/1LtgFER TOP VIDEOS
